justification: The interviewee states explicitly that they eat meat every day and, when asked why, responds 'because I like it.' Liking meat supports eating it daily.

stance_2: Meat is my main protein source
justification: The interviewee explicitly says eating meat daily is their main source of protein. These stances support each other.

stance_2: My family and friends eat meat regularly
justification: The regular meat-eating habits of the interviewee's social group make it more likely and easier for the interviewee to eat meat every day.

stance_2: Eating meat feels normal in my group
justification: The interviewee says eating meat feels normal in their group, which supports their own habit of eating meat every day.

stance_2: Meat is my main protein source
justification: The interviewee says they eat meat as their main protein source because they like it. Liking meat supports choosing it as a primary food.

stance_2: My family and friends eat meat regularly
justification: The interviewee assumes their family and friends eat meat regularly because they like it, which mirrors their own motivation.

stance_2: Eating meat feels normal in my group
justification: The interviewee's personal liking of meat aligns with the group norm, suggesting mutual reinforcement.

stance_1: Meat is my main protein source
stance_2: My family and friends eat meat regularly
justification: The interviewee's reliance on meat as a main protein source is facilitated by a household/social context where meat-eating is regular.

stance_1: Meat is my main protein source
stance_2: Eating meat feels normal in my group
justification: The normalization of meat-eating within the group supports using meat as a main protein source.

stance_1: Eating meat feels normal in my group
stance_2: My family and friends eat meat regularly
justification: The interviewee explicitly connects the regular meat-eating of their social group to the sense that eating meat is normal in their group.
